column9: OCLC: 11758181 ; Notes on the founding of the Virginia Society for the Promotion of Useful Knowledge. In emulation of English and Continental philosophical societies, the Virginia organization hoped to spur scientific inquiry and advances, especially in those branches of science which promoted industry, commerce, and the arts.

column9: The Society for the Promotion of Agriculture, Arts and Manufactures was founded in New York City in 1791 as a learned society; in 1797 the Society moved to Albany. In 1804, it changed its name to the Society for the Promotion of Useful Arts (SPUA). In 1824, the SPUA ceased its activities as a learned society when it merged with the Albany Lyceum of Natural History (a museum founded in 1823) to become the Albany Institute, a museum that exists to the present day.

Name: Massachusetts Society for Promoting Agriculture (MSPA)
column9: [The Society was responsible for numerous scholarly publications, primarily in the 19th century ( Harvard Univ. cat.). The headquarters of the Society are the Timothy Pickering Library in the Wenham Museum (see the section entitled The Collections).]

Lyceum of Natural History in the City of New York later renamed New York Academy of Sciences (NYAS)
Publication: Annals of the Lyceum of Natural History of New-York
column9: It should be noted that the Lyceum was founded only three years after the Literary and Philosophical Society of New-York. The two became rivals, in a sense, although the Lyceum was founded with a distinctly narrower scope, namely natural history. Not long after the founding of the Lyceum, the Society went into a protracted decline; its last recorded meeting occurred in 1834. By contrast, the Lyceum still exists, but under the name of New York Academy of Sciences.

Name: Medical Society of the District of Columbia
American Geological Society
column9: [According to Kraus (1921), the American Geological Society was founded in 1819 at Yale College. The membership included the illustrious Benjamin Silliman (1779-1864). The Society was short-lived, going out of existence in 1828. It seems clear that the American Geological Society was in some sense a precursor to the Association of American Geologists and Naturalists, which was founded in 1840 as the Association of American Geologists, and which ceased to exist on 1848, September 20, when its members convened to resolve their society into a new organization: the American Association for the Advancement of Science.]

Name: Delaware Chemical and Geological Society
column9: [According to both Bolton (1897), p.731, and Bogert (1908), p.167, this Society was founded on 1821, September 6 and was short-lived. It probably ceased well before 1830.]

Name: Association of American Geologists and Naturalists
Publication: Reports of the first, second, and third meetings of the Association of American Geologists and Naturalists, at Philadelphia in 1840 and 1841, and at Boston in 1842. Embracing its Proceedings and Transactions.
column9: According to Kraus (1921), the American Geological Society was founded in 1819 at Yale College. The membership included the illustrious Benjamin Silliman (1779_1864). The Society was short-lived, going out of existence in 1828. Kraus follows this discussion by going on to the Association of American Geologists. Although Kraus does not spell it out, it seems clear that the American Geological Society was in some sense a precursor to the Association of American Geologists.

Name: American Association for the Advancement of Science (AAAS)
Publication: Proceedings of the American Association for the Advancement of Science
column9: According to the Archives area of the American Association for the Advancement of Science website, the Association of American Geologists was founded in 1840, and in 1842, it became the Association of American Geologists and Naturalists. The Association ceased to exist on 1848, September 20, when its members convened to resolve their society into a new organization: the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

Name: Virginia Mechanics' Institute.
column9: An active movement among mechanics, journeymen, and employers resulted in the Virginia Mechanics Institute, organized in 1854. The vision of the founders was a broad educational endeavor, "to promote education in the scientific and mechanic arts and in other subjects relating to the conduct and development of business and industry." When the Virginia Mechanics Institute was incorporated in 1856, work began with a school of design and a night school. It provided a chemical laboratory, a library, public lectures, and an annual exhibit of the best inventions or works of Virginia mechanics (female as well as male). Virginia Mechanics Institute was a non-profit, non-stock Virginia corporation. It was exclusively an evening school, giving opportunities for technical education to boys and men who held jobs during the day or who were trying to find employment. Applicants had to be at least fifteen years old and of good moral character. During the long period of its independent existence, the institute received the liberal financial support of the City government which made it possible to maintain a schedule of very modest student fees.
